The Plinkit 2019 Holiday Gift Guide

Thoughtfully curated toys + books that are educational + fun. Expertly analyzed against our rigorous criteria. Approved by teachers, parents and children.

P.S. For nostalgia’s sake, the last year’s gift guide.

Critical Thinking Social + Emotional Language + Literacy Creativity + Imagination Fine Motor + Gross Motor WOW Factor Little Somethings Puzzles + Games Books We Love to Give
Critical Thinking
Café Plus LEGO Set

Proof that math is creative! A unique way to learn math in context. Sorting, matching, organizing – all early math concepts for opening your own café. Also inspires dramatic play, language-building and social skills.

Buy Now
Ages
2-3,
3-4
Creativity + Imagination
Critical Thinking
Ze Géoanimo Blocks

Up the ante on traditional pattern blocks. Beautifully designed by award-winning French author-illustrator Édouard Manceau. Curved shapes with unique pattern cards.

Buy Now
Ages
2-3,
3-4
Creativity + Imagination
Critical Thinking
Scoop-A-Bug

Bugs, scoopers, magnifiers – kid favorites jam-packed into one toy. Plus a pinch of counting, hand-eye coordination and muscle control. Creepy fun!

Buy Now
Ages
2-3,
3-4
Fine Motor + Gross Motor
Critical Thinking
Aircraft Engineer Kit

It’s rare that we find an ‘engineering’ toy for small hands. This nifty set has large and colorful pieces specially designed for just that reason. Makes 10 vehicles using foundational S.T.E.A.M skills.

Buy Now
Ages
3-4,
4-5
Creativity + Imagination
Critical Thinking
Science Experiment Toolbox

“If you love building, this is the perfect toy. It has really fun things that move your brain. Like gears.” (Said a 5-year old tester.) Learn about simple machines in 6 experiments. Compact design for easy clean-up.

Buy Now
Ages
4-5,
5-6
Fine Motor + Gross Motor
Critical Thinking
Woodworker’s Project Kit

Celebrate problem-solving through woodworking. Made by (their own) hands, made with love, built for purpose. For something more open-ended, try this toolbox set.

Buy Now
Ages
4-5,
5-6
Fine Motor + Gross Motor
Critical Thinking
Box and Balls

Deceptively simple. Rolling, bouncing, banking, stacking, nesting – your choice! An excellent game for developing concentration (key for executive functioning), hand-eye coordination and motor planning.

Buy Now
Ages
4-5,
5-6
Fine Motor + Gross Motor
Critical Thinking
Waterlily Challenge Game

Strategy + fun. Add dexterity…now you’re firing all sorts of brain connections. A game of skill that everyone can play.

Buy Now
Ages
4-5,
5-6
Fine Motor + Gross Motor
Critical Thinking
Social + Emotional
Dentist Play Set

Dramatic + dentist go hand-in-hand for the imagination. (Think: pliers + teeth!) Well-sized to build hand strength, essential for learning to write. Rolls up in an easy travel case.

Buy Now
Ages
2-3,
3-4
Creativity + Imagination
Social + Emotional
Portable Animal Clinic

“Look for the helpers.” -Mister Rogers. Teach empathy and build storytelling skills with this sweet vet clinic. Watch your little one creatively work through big feelings.

Buy Now
Ages
2-3,
3-4
Creativity + Imagination
Social + Emotional
Adventure Playground Kit

*Bendable* building blocks do exist! Use it to role play tricky playground social situations. Made in Germany and beloved among children and educators for over 30 years.

Buy Now
Ages
2-3,
3-4
Critical Thinking
Social + Emotional
Modular Building Play Set

Go beyond the traditional dollhouse. This flexible set has endless design options and brilliantly packs up. Plus, the beanbag characters are irresistibly squeezy (super for strengthening hand muscles).

Buy Now
Ages

4-5
Social + Emotional
Creativity + Imagination
Aki and Maki Sushi Game

A hard-to-find toy, but well worth it. From the felt ‘seaweed’ to the wooden ‘rice’ (can you spot 2 different shapes?), it’s excellent for sensory play and honing fine motor skills.

Buy Now
Ages
4-5,
5-6
Fine Motor + Gross Motor
Social + Emotional

Warning: We’ve seen kids love these so much that they never take them off. Pairs nicely with this best-selling kids cookbook.

The Fair Doll

Multiple award winner. This huggable lovey comes with a kindness kit – 10 tokens to give as a random acts of kindness. Join the mission to spread friendship, gratitude and fairness. Much love to the the Hope doll also.

Pindaloo

Move your brain and hands in a unique way (check out the video). You won’t even realize that they’re actively developing bilateral coordination and visual-spatial planning. Very cool.

Use bath time as a giggly play space for learning letters. (Ditto for learning numbers and quantities.)

Eat-It-Up Puppet

Feed the b-e-l-l-y! A glove puppet with an actual belly bag. Great for back-and-forth conversations. P.S. Puppets are a great tool for helping children navigate their social world from a different perspective.

Buy Now

3-4
Social + Emotional
Language + Literacy
Toy Cash Register

Just about everything kids love in a register: credit card reader, till, item scanner, number counter, push buttons. Check, check, check! Learning to count through role-play is effective + fun.

Buy Now

3-4
Creativity + Imagination

Alphabet Acorns

Because kids love little things hidden inside little things – do it with letters. Guess what’s hidden in each acorn? Clue: it’s a fun way to make connections between letter names and letter sounds.

Buy Now

HedBanz Jr.

Language + Literacy
Treasure Hunt Game

Scavenger hunts made easy. Use these clever cards to lead your kids to an unexpected surprise. Encourage sight word recognition, multi-step directions and persistence (all important parts of Kindergarten Readiness).

Lincoln Logs

Kid: “I want this! I play with it all the time at school.” Grown-up: “Really? Isn’t it just a bunch of logs?” Kid: “No, it’s awesome. You can build anything!!” True conversation we overheard. Sometimes simple is best for toys that last.

Life

See the world’s beauty through the eyes of animals. A moving experience with stunning illustrations. The modest text allows you to use the cueing system for emerging readers. Continue to inspire perspective with I Wonder.

Stormy

Breathtakingly beautiful. A wordless book where a picture tells a thousand words. Excellent for building storytelling skills, a key step in literacy development. In the same genre, try Tiger vs. Nightmare for something more animated with words.

5-6

Magical + fantastical. Daydreams are made of stories like this. An excellent read aloud that easily allows you to increase critical thinking and curiosity.

The Street Beneath My Feet

A fascinating explanation of what goes on underground from topsoil to the Earth’s mantle. Food for curious minds. The novel foldout format will take your little one on a journey for hours.

Moonshot

Otherworldly illustrations. “Reading Moonshot gave me the feeling I was back up in space.” -Michael Collins, Command Module Pilot, Apollo 11. Meanwhile back on earth, Mountains of the World is also captivating.
